On Jan. 1, 2000, when worldwide meltdown was widely forecast by doomsayers like de Jager, absolutely nothing happened. @WSJ

8/ Today, these men & women have spread out all over the U.S., including some who are now in Michigan. As an American whose ancestors left their home countries seeking a better life, I know that there‚Äôs no telling what these resilient people will do with this opportunity.

7/ As I told my team that morning, it‚Äôs not every day that you get to see something all the way through in government work. And it‚Äôs not every day that you get to greet the people on the receiving end of that work.

6/ The effort to get these folks through the streets of Kabul, into the airport, onto a flight to safety and, finally, to the U.S., was a long, emotional & tumultuous saga. To see them snake through the lines at Dulles to be processed for their new visa status was overwhelming.

5/ They were some of the first Afghans who'd been evacuated to other countries to land in the U.S. As I hugged them as they stepped off the plane, it was hard not to think that they were going through the same experiences my own ancestors did at Ellis Island not so long ago. http://pbs.twimg.com/media/Fb_YPA8XkAA4Wwd.png http://pbs.twimg.com/media/Fb_YQ-QXoBUUBuy.png http://pbs.twimg.com/media/Fb_YS9LXEAEIp9q.png http://pbs.twimg.com/media/Fb_YUvTXgAAVR2v.png

3/ In the months since the fall of Afghanistan, this group  had become an important part of our team‚Äôs work. My staff & I felt a responsibility to make sure they arrived safely in the U.S. after everything they had sacrificed on behalf of our country & our mission in Afghanistan.

2/ After months of engagement between the Albanian government and the Biden administration, in March, we finally got confirmation that our group of Afghans would be coming to the U.S. after a DHS team flew to Albania to complete the vetting process in-person.

HEAT STROKE

Signs: Extremely high body temperature (above 103 degrees), hot and dry skin with no sweat, rapid pulse, confusion, or unconsciousness.

Actions: Call 911 or get the person to a hospital immediately. Cool down with whatever methods are available until help arrives.

HEAT EXHAUSTION:

Signs: Heavy sweating, paleness, muscle cramps, weakness, dizziness, nausea, vomiting, or fainting.

Actions: Lie down in air-conditioning. Loosen clothing. Take sips of cool sports drinks with salt and sugar. Get medical help if symptoms get worse.
